channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: This Distant Planet Has a 350,000-Mile-Long Comet-Like Tail
item.description: The stream of helium trailing WASP-69b, a “Hot Jupiter,” allows astronomers to study how planets lose their atmospheres.
item.dc:creator: Robin George Andrews

item.title: New Origin Story for Tyrannosaurs Rex Suggested by Fossil
item.description: Researchers say the species they named Tyrannosaurus mcraeensis predated the dinosaur era’s great predator.
item.dc:creator: Asher Elbein

item.title: Scaly Fossil Is the Oldest-Known Piece of Skin
item.description: The specimen came from a 289 million-year-old fossil deposit and might offer clues to how skin evolved.
item.dc:creator: Kate Golembiewski

item.title: Researchers Scramble to Keep Dog Aging Project Alive
item.description: The National Institute on Aging may let funding lapse for a yearslong study of nearly 50,000 pet dogs, which could also offer insight into human health.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: The Dog Aging Project includes 47,000 canines and counting, and the data are starting to stream in. But its funding, provided almost entirely by the National Institute on Aging, will expire in a few months.

item.title: Ancient Skeletons Give Clues to Modern Medical Mysteries
item.description: DNA fragments from thousands of years ago are providing insights into multiple sclerosis, diabetes, schizophrenia and other illnesses.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: A 4,000-year-old skeleton of a Yamnaya person found in Bulgaria.

item.title: The Biggest Ape That Ever Lived Was Not Too Big to Fail
item.description: Fossil teeth reveal Gigantopithecus was doomed by a changing environment and an inflexible diet.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea

item.title: NASA Delays Artemis Astronaut Moon Missions
item.description: Artemis II, a trip around the moon, will now occur no earlier than September 2025 while a moon landing, Artemis III, will move to 2026.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The crew of Artemis II, from left: Victor Glover, pilot; Reid Wiseman, commander; Christina Hammock Koch, mission specialist; and the Canadian astronaut Jeremy Hansen, mission specialist, last year.

item.title: The New Space Race Is Causing New Pollution Problems
item.description: Earth’s stratosphere has never seen the amounts of emissions and waste from rockets and satellites that a booming space economy will leave behind.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Hall

item.title: How Astronomers Are Saving Astronomy From Satellites — For Now
item.description: Even the most powerful telescopes are in peril as orbits above Earth fill with thousands of new satellites. But scientists aren’t ready to give up the night sky.
item.dc:creator: Lyndie Chiou

item.title: FEMA’s Disaster Map Is Getting Crowded
item.description: Each weekday morning, FEMA releases a map showing weather hazards around the country. It’s starting to get a little out of hand.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:description: FEMA’s national map showing hazards expected to start on Jan. 13, 2024, including variations of snow, wind, cold, rain and floods affecting most of the country.

item.title: The Billionaires Spending a Fortune to Lure Scientists Away From Universities
item.description: Arena BioWorks is promising big paydays to nearly 100 researchers from Harvard, M.I.T. and other prestigious institutions.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland
item.media:credit: Bob O'Connor for The New York Times
item.media:description: Among the early backers of Arena BioWorks are Stephen Pagliuca, the Boston Celtics owner, far left; and Thomas Cahill, a Boston venture capitalist, second from right. Stuart Schreiber, far right, a longtime Harvard-affiliated researcher, quit to be Arena’s lead scientist; and Keith Joung, seated, is among Arena’s newest hires.

item.title: Drought Touches a Quarter of Humanity, U.N. Says, Disrupting Lives Globally
item.description: The crisis, worsened partly by climate change, has been accompanied by soaring food prices and could have consequences for hunger, elections and migration worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
item.media:description: The shrinking Lake Titicaca, between Peru and Bolivia in the Andes, is Latin America’s largest freshwater basin.

item.title: Looming Starvation in Gaza Shows Resurgence of Civilian Sieges in Warfare
item.description: A U.N.-affiliated panel said the territory could tip into famine very soon. International laws to protect people from human-made famines offer little help.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Palestinians lined up to collect drinking water in Rafah, southern Gaza, last week.

item.title: What Happens When There Is No Food: Experts Say Severe Malnutrition Could Set in Swiftly in Gaza
item.description: Nutrition experts say the progression from hunger to severe malnutrition can be rapid, especially in children.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Making bread at tents amid the rubble of a destroyed building in Rafah, in southern Gaza.

item.title: Rare Whale Off South Carolina Coast Is Expected to Die From Injuries
item.description: Efforts to reduce boat speed limits near the habitat of the critically endangered species have been unsuccessful, with fewer than 360 of the whales remaining.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: A North Atlantic right whale mother, known as Juno, with its then-newborn calf off South Carolina in November. The calf is seriously injured and not expected to survive.

item.title: Women With Depression During or After Pregnancy Face Greater Suicide Risk, Even Years Later
item.description: Two studies concluded that depression that began in pregnancy or soon after could have troubling implications for as long as 18 years.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times

item.title: Use of ADHD Drugs Surged During Pandemic, Study Finds
item.description: Social media influencers and online marketing may have played a role, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:description: During the coronavirus pandemic, prescriptions of stimulants used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder rose 30 percent among people ages 20 to 39, while prescriptions of non-stimulant A.D.H.D. medications rose 81 percent.

item.title: ‘Gas-Station Heroin’ Sold as Dietary Supplement Alarms Health Officials
item.description: Tianeptine, found at convenience stores, at smoke shops and online, can mimic an opioid. It is among a growing class of substances that are difficult to control.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neptune’s Fix, a shot sold at convenience stores and gas stations that contains an ingredient called tianeptine, is part of a growing class of unregulated and potentially addictive products becoming more widely available.

item.title: Climate Change Is Driving a Sharp Drop in Snow Levels, Study Finds
item.description: Parts of the Northern Hemisphere are warming enough that their prospects of future snow are rapidly declining.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: The view from a National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration snow survey flight above the High Sierras in March.

item.title: U.S. Carbon Emissions Fell in 2023 as Coal Use Tumbled to New Lows
item.description: The drop was big, but emissions will need to fall three times as fast for the rest of the decade if the country wants to meet its climate goals.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer

item.title: We Are in a Big Covid Wave. But Just How Big?
item.description: Wastewater data has become perhaps the best metric to track the spread of the virus in the U.S., but it’s an imperfect tool.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Paris

item.title: An Ultrasound Experiment Tackles a Giant Problem in Brain Medicine
item.description: The effects of drugs that treat Alzheimer’s, cancer and other illnesses are often limited by the blood-brain barrier. A small study suggests a way forward.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata

item.title: Why Are California’s Waters Lighting Up in Blue?
item.description: It looks like the trailer for “Avatar: The Way of Water,” but it’s a natural phenomenon. And spotting it is getting increasingly popular.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: What is that bright blue glow in the waves of Huntington Beach in California? Bioluminescent algae.

item.title: 2023 Was Hottest Year on Record by a Lot
item.description: Month after month global temperatures didn’t just break records, they surpassed them by far. This year could be even warmer.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Keith Collins

item.title: F.D.A. Warned of Mental Side Effects from Asthma Drug, Singulair. Few Were Told.
item.description: Singulair, now a generic, is still used by millions of people in the United States even after thousands of patients and dozens of studies have described harm.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Johns Hopkins Center for Drug Safety and Effectiveness
item.media:credit: Niki Chan Wylie for The New York Times

item.title: Protecting the Ancient Beech Trees of Romania
item.description: In Romania, a walk in the woods blossomed into a mission to safeguard centuries-old beeches and the history that shaped them.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas J. R. White and Alan Burdick

item.title: Moon Lander Malfunctions After Launch, Raising Questions for NASA
item.description: After a flawless launch to orbit, the privately built robotic Peregrine lander is unlikely to reach the lunar surface because of a failure in its propulsion system.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: NASA, via Agence France-Press — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Astrobotic Peregrine lunar lander during preparations for launch in Florida in November.

item.title: How 2024 Will Be A.I.’s ‘Leap Forward’
item.description: A.I. is set to advance at a rapid rate, becoming more powerful and spreading into the physical world.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz

item.title: Vulcan Rocket Aces Its First Launch
item.description: Despite problems with one of its payloads, the new launcher’s flight was flawless, showing the potential of several vehicles that could chip away at SpaceX’s dominance.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: United Launch Alliance’s (ULA) Vulcan Centaur, lifting off from Cape Canaveral, Florida, on Monday.

item.title: What to Know About the ULA Vulcan Rocket Mission
item.description: Here’s what you need to know about United Launch Alliance and the robotic lunar spacecraft it is sending to orbit.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The United Launch Alliance Vulcan Centaur rocket on Sunday near dusk.

item.title: The Mystery of the Coin That Shouldn’t Exist
item.description: Scientists recently analyzed a Peruvian 10-cent piece with an unexplained origin.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Kornei

item.title: The Income Gap Jeopardizing Retirement for Millions
item.description: Americans in the lower middle class are losing ground financially, researchers have found.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:description: Monique Louvigny, who lives in Vallejo, Calif., was laid off at age 57 and now freelances as an events coordinator. Her income has fallen to less than $30,000 a year.

item.title: Can $500 Million Save This Glacier?
item.description: A bold engineering project might show a way to slow sea-level rise — and bring new imagination to the fight against climate change.
item.dc:creator: Jon Gertner
item.media:credit: Olaf Otto Becker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jakobshavn glacier in Greenland. Glaciologists have identified it as one of the fastest-deteriorating glaciers in the world.

item.title: Galaxies in the Early Universe Were Shaped Like Bananas, Study Suggests
item.description: Images from the Webb telescope suggest that newborn galaxies look weirder than expected. Exactly how screwy was physics at the dawn of time?
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
